content.description:
Scorsese is a jaw-dropping line on a cliff with a sea of them. It is hard to believe there are actually perfectly sculpted holds up this amazing, overhanging prow of orange, green, and white granite.

Start by climbing the first pitch of "

Pura Aventura

, 5.11". Small gear can be used here on the left crack. From the ledge, climb into an arching finger crack before moving back right to the arete. Launch into the compression crux followed immediately by pumpy 5.13 climbing. Rest up at the final jug before performing the crux dyno to the chains.
content.protection: A standard rack to 1", then about 12 bolts + a 2-bolt anchor.
content.location:
It is on the right side of the South Ridge, looming over the first pitch of

Pura Aventura

.

content.description: This is the longest route at Boston Peak. It is another McCorkel masterpiece following a series of ledges and corners all the way to the summit.
content.location: On the right side of the South Ridge is the first pitch. Noted by a pair of cracks, the right crack is quite wide.

content.description:
Marky Mark is a shorter, power endurance based route that has a bunch of really technical climbing on rad edges, sidepulls and underclings.

Start with big moves on good holds to reach the crux at bolt 3. A techy highstep leads to a cool sloper and a foot intensive move to a good undercling. A few more strenuous 5.11 moves get you to the anchor.
content.location:
This is on the left side of the South Ridge, to the right of

Freedom Trail

.

content.description:
This awesome pillar feature is named after the infamous Massachusetts serial killer who claimed to have killed 33 people.

Start up the ramp/chimney feature to gain the squeeze pillar. Excellent 5.12 arete climbing leads to a hard crux right before the angle change. Enjoy a nice stance on the vertical wall before launching into the long final slab that is full of intimidating but excellent movement. This is one of the best slab climbs in the canyon.
content.location: It is on the left side of the South Ridge.

content.description:
This is a fun outing on nice rock with lots of edges and some tricky foot work.

Start by stemming up a chimney until you can gain good edges and start moving up and left onto the face. The hardest move is probably right before the 3rd bolt moving off an angled rail to a nice flat edge. Above the ledge, the climbing is slabby but engaging and cerebral.
content.location:
It is just right of

Marky Mark

on the left side of the South Corridor.

climbs.name: Freedom Trail
climbs.fa: B. Scott, D. Mckee, J. Tarry, P. Hurtgen

content.description:
Named after the famous tourist sightseeing walk around Boston, this climb is also for everyone.

An initial (V3/4) boulder problem can be skipped by pulling past the first bolt to better holds. Eliminating the first problem makes the route a really fun 5.10ish warm-up for the South Corridor. After the A0 start, continue on big hand holds with slopey feet at times up the obvious rail feature. A final slopey stand up guards the chains.
content.location: It is on the far left side of the South Ridge before you turn and head up to the Hall of Fame.

climbs.name: Donnie Loves Jenny
climbs.fa: C. Martin, R. D. Pascoe, B. Scott

content.description:
This ascends a great little panel of rock that works as an excellent warm-up for the routes near it.

Start with good edges to reach the arete feature on the left. A cruxy stand-up move at the 4th bolt leads to easier terrain and the anchor. This is super fun!
content.location:
It is in the center of the South Ridge area, just before you get to

Marky Mark

when walking uphill.
